titleStmt.title: Letter from Amy Lowell to Richard Aldington, March 25, 1916
titleStmt.author: Amy Lowell

physDesc.p: The letter consists of three sheets of paper with typewriting on both sides of each. At the top of each page except the first there is “R.A.” and the page number in the left corner and the date in the right corner. There is a watermark on the paper that reads “Berkshire Linen U.S.A.” Following the document of the letter are three delivery receipts. Each is the size of 1/3 sheet of paper. The first is perforated at the top and bottom, the second is torn at the top with a jagged edge, and the third has a jagged edge on both the top and bottom. The first receipt is for Letter Parcel number 14833. “Fenway Station” is stamped on the P.O. (post office) line. The writing on the receipt, in pencil, is difficult to read, but it appears to say that it was received for registration by “Lowell, Heath St.” The “addressed to” says Richard Aldington, Paracombe [illegible] Devon, Engl. The signature over “To addressee or order” is illegible. The second receipt is for Letter Parcel 15688, also from Fenway Station. The recipient is, again, Lowell, Heath St., with a word after “St.” that starts with B. The addressee is Richard Aldington, Esq, North Devonshire, Eng, Garcombe. The third receipt does not have a legible number, though it ends with “203.” The date appears to be April 20th (4-20). The recipient is “A. Lowell, Heath St.” The addressee is R. Aldington, Paracombe Engl.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I am sorry to say that Brown did not pay up on the 15th, as he agreed to do. As I told him that I should put the matter into the hands of a lawyer if he did not pay on that day, I put it into the hands of my brother-in-law, with the very unsatisfactory result that he reports, after investigation, that Brown’s business is mortgaged, so that it is almost impossible to get anything out of him, and the property cannot be attached on this account, apparently. We have forced him to engage a lawyer to defend himself, which is something; but, of course, there is no use carrying it into court, as it would merely run him into bankruptcy – which would be only a name, as he has nothing to lose by going bankrupt – and he could start business again under another name. Will does not at all advise suing him, therefore, but thinks that we shall get the thirty dollars that he owes you before very long, as Brown’s lawyer says he has some assets which will come in shortly.

I am enclosing a power of attorney which Will has given me, because whatever I do or say, Brown replies that he has had other instructions from you; and, of course, for two people to do business with any results at this distance is impossible. If I am to consider myself your agent in regard to your American affairs, I must be able to make myself obeyed by the publishers, and I cannot do that legally without a power of attorney. If, on the other hand, you do not wish to sign this power of attorney (which, it seems to me, you very possibly may not), I think it would be best for you to do all your business yourself by letter. But I appreciate the almost impossibility of doing this at such a distance, and with the mail in such a condition as it is between here and England; and I shall be perfectly delighted to act as your agent in every instance that you desire, but I must have this power of attorney.

Here is another instance: when you wrote to Fletcher that if we had withdrawn our poems from Kreymborg’s Anthology you would like to have yours withdrawn also, Fletcher and I talked it over together and decided that it would be better for me to write to Kreymborg, rather than for him to do so. I therefore wrote to Kreymborg, saying that you had sent instructions that if we had withdrawn our poems you wished to have yours withdrawn also. I have just seen a review of Kreymborg’s Anthology in which they speak of a poem of yours. I feel sure that Mr. Kreymborg would have obeyed my orders had he not received a later letter from you giving him different ones, - a letter which you presumably wrote without knowing what we had done about the matter. If I knew whether you had written or not, I could take some steps in the matter. If I had this power of attorney I could prevent the publication of that Anthology until a new edition could be got out without your poems. As it is, I can do nothing without knowing how you have acted in the matter. It is a fearful business running anybody else’s affairs! I try to do the best possible thing I can, and what I think you would like to have me do; and, of course, I very often don’t succeed.

Brown has certainly been an awful mess; but the book is out. I have a copy here, and I suppose he sent you one. I will try and find out whether he has or not, and if not, get you one and send it. It is not as attractive as the English edition, but it is not at all bad, and I am delighted to have it on the market, as long as we can not stop its publication. And I don’t really know that if we stopped the publication it would be of any advantage. You may sell a few copies here, even through Brown, although I believe his financial affairs are such that his publications are not handled generally by booksellers.

I am most sincerely sorry that I got you in for all this, but nobody spoke of Brown as dishonest at the time I suggested his writing to you about our book, and now everybody speaks of him as dishonest; and there you are!

I think in working for your interests here (if you decide to entrust them to me), it would be better to leave them entirely in my hands, and not write some of your instructions to Fletcher. It is quite impossible to say how long Fletcher will remain in this part of the country, although I am delighted to say I think he is quite settled down here and seems to enjoy himself. But even as it is, he acts on his part, and I act on mine, and you act on yours, and the situation is quite impossible, from a business point of view. Fletcher is not very practical, although full of enthusiasm and energy, and I often have to act as a go-between between him and editors here – or, rather, I have to straighten out unfortunate situations which his impetuosities create for him.

Now, as I said before, if you prefer to run all your own affairs, do not hesitate to tell me. I cannot say that I think I have made a brilliant success of your affairs so far, but you can be quite sure that that is not from want of trying. Only, I should like some definite instructions from you as to whether I am to consider myself your legal agent, with power of attorney, or not. If the former, I should, of course, have the power to sign contracts and manage your affairs as I should my own, - collect your royalties and transmit the money to you as I do on the “Imagist Anthology”. If I am not to be your agent, I think it would be better to have all this work sent direct to England, with the exception, of course, of the “Imagist Anthology”, as I am the holder of the contract for that work, and it is in my name. I think the method that has hitherto pertained should be adhered to under all circumstances.

Fletcher tells me that he wrote you in regard to the little notice of courtesy which we have been obliged to put in the “Anthology” for Harriet Monroe. Miss Monroe was very much upset last year at not being specially referred to in our Preface. She considers that she gave the movement its first start – and I think we must admit that she did. I have just been in Chicago, lecturing, and I saw Miss Monroe and told her that we were, none of us, overpleased with the way she was treating us now; that we did not consider that she published us enough, nor did we consider that she mentioned us enough in her editorials. I think I made some little impression, but not as much as I could wish. Talking to Harriet is a good deal like trying to dent a Scotch mist.

Last year, when she wrote to us, she was in an especially annoyed frame of mind; and in order to appease her wrath, which Ferris Greenslet seemed to think was extremely worth appeasing, he strongly advised me to promise to put some notice of her into the Preface of this “Anthology”. I should have told you at the time, but I am afraid it slipped my mind. This Preface being all written, Fletcher and I decided that it would be impossible to put the notice in the Preface. We therefore have incorporated a short paragraph among the acknowledgements. As I told you, the book had to go to press, and there was not time to consult you when I remembered it, and the matter was so trifling, I did not think that you would mind very much. But I certainly will try to be more business-like in future, and not commit my fellow-Imagists to anything without their consent.

My lecture in Chicago was called “The New Poetry, With a Special Reference to Imagism”, and was given in Maurice Brown’s [sic] Little Theatre. He is Harold Munro’s [sic] brother-in-law. The auditorium is small, but it was crammed to overflowing, with people in the aisles, in defiance of the police regulations; and, as it was, they had to turn a hundred away from the door, as there were no seats for them. The interest aroused was really quite extraordinary. I read selections from all of us, and I think it should distinctly help the sale of the new “Anthology” and of your book.

I am sending you a rather amusing book of Louis Untermeyer’s, in which appear a number of parodies. They come out in the New York Tribune, and, I think, will amuse you. I am sorry that none of you appear in the parodies, but at the time he wrote them I did not know him, and so was not able to read you and read you to him and impress upon him that we should be represented in any book of the sort. I think he only took me because of my Polyphonic Prose, which it amused him to do. In fact, we made acquaintance originally over this parody, which he sent to me with an apology. It is an extremely clever book, and, I am sure, will amuse you and Hilda.
Please give a great deal of love to Hilda, and please write soon. I miss your letters very much, and I have not heard from either you or Hilda for a long time.
I returned from Chicago this morning, and Fletcher tells me he understands our “Anthology” is not to be out until the 13th of April. They have certainly sent me no proofs yet, which is most annoying.
body.closer: With a great deal of love to you both,

div.note: Aldington ultimately publishes his book, Images, Old and New (1916), with Edmund R. Brown's press, Four Seas.
